stem: Dr. {{candidate_name}}, describe the surgical anatomy relevant to performing a tracheostomy.

prompts.text: What are the surface landmarks you would identify before starting?
expectedKeyFacts: Cricoid cartilage — palpable landmark
Sternal notch — inferior limit
Tracheal rings palpable between these landmarks
Midline identification

prompts.text: Describe the structures you would encounter from skin to trachea.
expectedKeyFacts: Skin and subcutaneous fat
Platysma
Investing layer of deep cervical fascia
Strap muscles (sternohyoid, sternothyroid) — separated in midline
Pretracheal fascia
Thyroid isthmus — overlies tracheal rings 2-4
Trachea — target rings 2-3

prompts.text: What vascular structures are at risk, and how would you manage unexpected bleeding?
expectedKeyFacts: Anterior jugular veins — laterally in superficial layers
Thyroid ima artery — present in ~10%, midline ascending vessel
Inferior thyroid veins
Brachiocephalic artery — at risk in children or low tracheostomy
Management: direct pressure, diathermy, ligate, call for surgical help

prompts.text: Why is the second or third tracheal ring preferred over the first ring or the cricothyroid membrane?
expectedKeyFacts: First ring — risk of subglottic stenosis from proximity to cricoid
Cricothyroid membrane — reserved for emergency, risk of vocal cord damage
Rings 2-3 provide good access with minimal stenosis risk
Below isthmus in most patients
Sufficient distance from both cricoid and brachiocephalic artery

rescuePrompt: Can you describe the tracheal rings and their relationship to the thyroid gland?
keyFacts: Skin → platysma → strap muscles → thyroid isthmus → trachea
Brachiocephalic artery at risk in children and low tracheostomy
Recurrent laryngeal nerves in tracheo-oesophageal groove
Posterior tracheal wall is membranous — risk of oesophageal injury

scoringGuidance.pass: Correctly describes the major layers, identifies isthmus position, aware of anterior jugular veins and brachiocephalic artery risk, knows preferred ring level; stronger candidates may give a layer-by-layer description unprompted and name variant vessels such as the ima artery
scoringGuidance.borderline: Incomplete layer description, may miss isthmus relationship or confuse ring levels, vague on vascular risks
scoringGuidance.fail: Cannot describe basic layers, unaware of thyroid isthmus position, does not identify major vascular risks
